data.title: No way to scope a grammar capture
data.body:
### Description There is no way to scope a grammar capture for specific grammar rules, leading to very odd, buggy-looking syntax highlights. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Set the language to any that has a rule that features both of the following. `language-gfm` and `language-javascript` both fulfill this requirement in their grammars. - A `begin` and `end` capture - A `pattern` that delegates to another language that also has a rule containing both a `begin` and `end` capture. (It doesn't have to delegate, though.) 2. Create something that matches that rule. For GFM, a code block tagged with `css` would suffice, and for JS, a tagged template starting with `html` would work. 3. Within that block, type something that would match the `begin` half of any rule in the other language that includes both a `begin` and `end`. Do not include the end. For GFM or JS, just start a comment in CSS or HTML, respectively. 4. Observe very odd syntax highlighting. It looks like a bug because it can't be contained, and repros 100% of the time. If you followed the above repro, the code might look like this pre-syntax highlighting:

  • GFM -> CSS 

    ```css
    
/* This is an unterminated comment
    
```
    

    
Some more text...

  • JS -> HTML 

    html`
    
<!-- This is an unterminated comment
    
`;
    

    
someOtherCall();
Here's a few screenshots of other code. `language-gfm` -> `language-javascript`: ![screenshot from 2016-10-24 23-47-59](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4483844/19672425/57f076e8-9a44-11e6-8776-4ebaf959af1b.png) `language-javascript` -> `language-html` ![screenshot from 2016-10-24 23-52-48](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4483844/19672495/0a6b770a-9a45-11e6-85a4-4ec7ef657b93.png) ### Versions OS: Ubuntu GNOME 14.04 (although it's been repro'd in Windows by others) Atom: v1.12.5 (been going on for quite a while) ### Additional Information Initially reported in atom/language-gfm#171, but I filed it here because it's language-agnostic.

data.title: Bad performance editing a line after many blank lines
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
* [X] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
* [X] Tried disabling every package in safe mode on a clean install
* [X] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
* [X] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
* [X] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Text operations (inserting / deleting characters, pasting, etc.) on a line that is preceded by many blank lines take a really long time.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new file.
2. Paste about 2000 blank lines (the performance gradually decreases with the amount of lines, for me 2000 is where it's already very noticeable).
3. Try to type something.

**Expected behavior:** Characters are inserted instantly.

**Actual behavior:** Individual characters take about 2 seconds to insert, typing many characters at once makes the editor hang for about 10 seconds before inserting them all at once.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

Linux 4.8.13-1-ARCH #1 SMP PREEMPT Fri Dec 9 07:24:34 CET 2016 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

### Profiler log
Trying to save the profiler log produced an empty file for some reason, here's a screenshot:
![Profiler log](https://i.imgur.com/4gPdAH7.png)

data.title: Uncaught Error: Notification must be created with string message: undefined
data.body:
Steps to reproduce below

1. Right click on a variable and pick Rename Identifier
2. Enter the new name in text field, hit enter 

**Atom Version**: 1.12.7
**Electron Version**: 1.3.13
**System**: Mac OS X 10.10.5
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

Uncaught Error: Notification must be created with string message: undefined

```

Error: Notification must be created with string message: undefined
```

data.title: directory lock problem
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When I build, I want to delete the folder that contains the output that was created earlier and create a new folder
It's okay to erase the folder, but when I try to recreate the folder with the same name, it creates an error when file-tree of that folder is open in Atom.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. open some folder file tree on atom 
2. rmdir that folder
3. mkdir folder with the same name
4. Error occur

**Expected behavior:** directory cleared

**Actual behavior:** emit error: `Error: EPERM: operation not permitted, mkdir`

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Window 10 64bit

Atom    : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

![img](http://i.imgur.com/CevMvek.png)

data.title: When you have Atom running on Mac OS X Mavericks or Sierra and choose Restart, it will prevent the restart
data.body:
I am using Atom 1.12.7 
On Mavericks, it will block the Mac's restart by showing a dialog that says Cancel or Try Again.
On Sierra, it will show that same dialog (about cannot restart), but will restart _anyway_

(note that nothing was edited, meaning there is no "unsaved content" so restart should not be blocked).

data.title: Don't hard-code "Atom.app"
data.body:
and a few typos

### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

<!--

We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts.

-->

### Alternate Designs

The change seems harmless, and makes reporting more exact.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Already in core

### Benefits

User will get a lss confusing  error message for Atom Beta

### Possible Drawbacks

none

### Applicable Issues

none known

data.title: Paste indentation issue with auto-indent off
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Paste apparently takes the current indentation into account, even when Auto Indent and Auto Indent On Paste are off. This happens in any grammar, including plain text.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Type the following:
```
a
  b
    c
```
2. Copy from (and including) the new-line at the end of the first line, upto the end of the second line. Go to the end of the third line, and paste.

**Expected behavior:** The result should be:
```
a
  b
    c
  b
```

**Actual behavior:** The result is:
```
a
  b
    c
      b
```

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome : 52.0.2743.82
Node : 6.5.0

apm 1.12.9
npm 3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python
git
visual studio 2013

Windows 8.1

### Additional Information

![gif](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/24660923/21487661/17adbdc2-cbcf-11e6-95b4-5e271dd68e8e.gif)

data.title: :memo: Update issue and PR templates
data.body: Fix typo in template heading

data.title: [wish-list] Can atom have some standard infrastructures like quickfix window ?
data.body:
I was a vim/emacs user before. after switching from vim to emacs I found the most unaccaptable thing is emacs is lack of standard infrastructures, after switching from Emacs to Atom I found same problem.

May I have a chance to explain why standard infrastructures are important to an editor ?

Let me take emacs as an example:

Emacs is lack of standard infrastructures like quickfix, jumplist, buflisted, preview window etc. Yes, I know elisp can implement such things. but once again, no standard. You can implement your own one, but no package will use it. You can't modify every single package yourself to get corresponding experience. Every package in emacs implement their own quickfix window, so when I build my project or run grep, or search a tag, many different windows are open. many different buffers are created. But Vim got standard quickfix, preview window , jump list and provide corresponding API to plugins. Many plugins in vim work with them. Compilation and grepping and tag searching plugins will all display them result in quickfix window and other plugins will highlight my source code by analyzing the content in quickfix they are fully cooperative. But in emacs each one has their own implementation just like many fragments. I was tired from swithing buffers and windows and killing many outdated buffers. In vim I never feel it like a burden.

Now I am using Atom as my main editor, I even write [a package](https://atom.io/packages/atom-shell-commands) for Atom which has more than 5000+ downloads. I found the same problem in both Emacs and Atom: Each packages are trying to implement their quickfix window, too many fragments. A lot of different quickfix/location list like panels from different packages occupy my screen space, I have to keep closing or folding newly open panels again and again, some of them are still buggy or have limitation (atom-message-panel).

If Atom can provide a standard quickfix window / location list / preview window , packages will work with them and get cooperative. Compilation result can be display in quickfix window in realtime, tag result can display in quickfix and so does grep result, linting result. Some packages analyse data from it. And most important thing is people can get corresponding experience from different packages in Atom.

Or at least, have a tab manager in the bottom panel, each package can use a tab in the bottom panel. not pile up. We can open a quickfix window and a mini terminal and a manual help window in different tabs in the bottom panel at the same time. Now if I am using two packages which will both display a panel in the bottom of the window, my workspace is totally messed up.

data.title: Atom gets stuck when searching for something common in a large project
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom gets stuck when searching for something very common in a large project.

### Steps to Reproduce

Open a folder with a large project.
Press ctrl shift f to look in the whole project.
Search for something very common like 'console.log('
Atom window gets stuck, I see the number of matches slowly rise to thousands and then it stops.
There's no way to stop the search other than closing down the window.

**Expected behavior:**

To not get stuck and to be able to stop the search.

**Actual behavior:**

Window hangs.

**Reproduces how often:** 

Always.

### Versions

1.12.7 on Windows 10.

### Additional Information

With notepad++ I get about 2500 matches in the same folder.

data.title: Non-Keypad Number Key Keystrokes Ignored with htm/html files
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages


### Description

When editing files with the extension .htm or .html the number keys (non keypad number keys) are not working however they do work when you press shift and the number key equivalent e.g. 

> !@£$%^&*()_+

I've confirmed this by copying an htm file as filename.htm and filename.txt

The above is not reproducible with the file with the .txt extension.
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open atom (either via macOS UI Applications or via terminal)
2. In atom open any html file with extension .htm or .html
3. Whilst editing the html file press any number key (non keypad as I'm using a MacBook Pro)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

A number to appear at the cursor

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Keystroke ignored

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

1.12.7 production release
1.13.0-beta8 beta release

data.title: Atom on Windows does not load when disconnected from Internet
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When my computer is disconnected from the Internet, Atom does not load.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Disconnect from Internet.
2. Try to run Atom.

**Expected behavior:** Atom opens.

**Actual behavior:** Atom does not open.

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

```shell
PS C:\Users\Workstation> atom --version
Atom    : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

PS C:\Users\Workstation> apm --version
apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.10.1.windows.1
visual studio
```

### Additional Information

I am running Windows 10.

I have tried running Atom from the Start Menu, from its EXE, and from the command line.  None of these work.

Running `atom --safe` does not work. Even `atom --version` does not work when the Internet is disconnected.

I am on a laptop with WiFi.

There is nothing in `%TEMP%\Atom Crashes`.

data.title: Add atom.tooltips.findTooltips(target)
data.body:
Right now, it is not possible to hide a tooltip programatically. This is useful when we know better than the tooltip implementation that we did an action that should hide it.

After discussing with @lee-dohm, he suggested the findTooltips API that mimicks the KeyMapManager API.

Released under CC0

data.title: dev/packages folder linked to SMB mount won't show up
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I want to start developing a new derived package from a known one. I run `atom` on windows. When linking my package folder (which resides in my home dir in linux and is mounted on a SAMBA share in windows), the `.atom/dev/packages` hierarchy in the `atom` pane remains empty (also in developer mode).

### Steps to Reproduce

1. in windows `cmd` I go to my mounted folder: `C:\Users\ggreif>pushd Z:\ide-haskell-repl`

2. I link it to `atom`:
```
Z:\ide-haskell-repl>apm link --dev
INFO: Could not find files for the given pattern(s).
The system cannot find the file specified.
C:\Users\ggreif\.atom\dev\packages\ide-haskell-repl -> Z:\ide-haskell-repl
```
3. I start in dev mode: `Z:\ide-haskell-repl>atom -d`
4. I open up the "Settings" pane and hit the `Open Config Folder` button
5. I observe: the `dev/packages` hierarchy is empty.
6. I confirm that the folder is indeed linked:
```
Z:\ide-haskell-repl>popd
C:\Users\ggreif>dir .atom\dev
 Volume in drive C is System
 Volume Serial Number is XXXXXXX

 Directory of C:\Users\ggreif\.atom\dev

30.11.2016  17:04    <DIR>          .
30.11.2016  17:04    <DIR>          ..
22.12.2016  14:15    <DIR>          packages
               0 File(s)              0 bytes
               3 Dir(s)  231.205.515.264 bytes free

C:\Users\ggreif>dir .atom\dev\packages
 Volume in drive C is System
 Volume Serial Number is XXXXXXX

 Directory of C:\Users\ggreif\.atom\dev\packages

22.12.2016  14:15    <DIR>          .
22.12.2016  14:15    <DIR>          ..
22.12.2016  14:15    <JUNCTION>     ide-haskell-repl [Z:\ide-haskell-repl]
               0 File(s)              0 bytes
               3 Dir(s)  231.205.515.264 bytes free
```

**Expected behavior:** I'd expect that my linked package shows up under `dev/packages`
**Actual behavior:** It doesn't

**Reproduces how often:** Happens always I try it.

### Versions

OS: Windows 7 Professional

Z:\hyper-haskell>atom --version

Atom    : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

Z:\hyper-haskell>apm --version
INFO: Could not find files for the given pattern(s).
The system cannot find the file specified.
apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python
git
visual studio

data.title: Hang on when clicking checking for updates
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * [x] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * [x] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7857126/21423641/22a314e2-c879-11e6-8c5c-18509cf607a6.png)

Can not close the alert window.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Atom -> Checking for updates
2. Before the alert window appearing, reclick the Atom menu.
3. And then the alert window appeared, but can't be closed. You need to kill atom process manually.

**Expected behavior:** After doing 1 & 2, we can still close the window.

**Actual behavior:** After doing 1 & 2, we can't close window.

**Reproduces how often:** Everytime I test in that behaviour.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

Even though this problem doesn't affect using, but still a bug need to be fixed.

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'isGreaterThan' of null
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When on the first column of an empty line, trying to increment the indentation through the `editor:indent` will raise an exception instead of increasing the indentation. This does not occurs when the cursor is no longer at the beginning of the line nor when the line is not empty.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Place the cursor at the beginning of an empty line
2. Trigger the `editor:indent` command

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

The line should have been indented and the cursor moved to the new position

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

An uncaught exception is raised.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

```
> atom --version
Atom    : 1.14.0-dev-2958ad2
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

> apm --version
apm  1.15.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.11
git 2.10.1
```

### Stack Trace

`Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'isGreaterThan' of null`

<details>

```
At /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/text-buffer.js:825

TypeError: Cannot read property 'isGreaterThan' of null
    at Cursor.module.exports.Cursor.skipLeadingWhitespace (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/cursor.js:406:33)
    at Selection.module.exports.Selection.indent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/selection.js:785:21)
    at /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:2807:26
    at /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:1130:28
    at TextBuffer.module.exports.TextBuffer.transact (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/text-buffer.js:820:18)
    at TextEditor.module.exports.TextEditor.transact (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:1547:26)
    at /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:1124:24
    at TextEditor.module.exports.TextEditor.mergeSelections (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:2521:43)
    at TextEditor.module.exports.TextEditor.mergeIntersectingSelections (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:2487:35)
    at TextEditor.module.exports.TextEditor.mutateSelectedText (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:1122:19)
    at TextEditor.module.exports.TextEditor.indent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:2806:19)
    at TextEditor.editor:indent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/register-default-commands.js:594:21)
    at /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/register-default-commands.js:666:34
    at TextBuffer.module.exports.TextBuffer.transact (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/text-buffer.js:820:18)
    at TextEditor.module.exports.TextEditor.transact (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:1547:26)
    at atom-text-editor.newCommandListeners.(anonymous function) (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/register-default-commands.js:665:22)
    at CommandRegistry.module.exports.CommandRegistry.handleCommandEvent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/command-registry.js:259:29)
    at /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/command-registry.js:3:59
    at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.dispatchCommandEvent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:599:16)
    at KeymapManager.module.exports.KeymapManager.handleKeyboardEvent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/atom-keymap/lib/keymap-manager.js:390:22)
    at WindowEventHandler.module.exports.WindowEventHandler.handleDocumentKeyEvent (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/window-event-handler.js:106:36)
    at HTMLDocument.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/window-event-handler.js:3:59)
```

</details>

### Commands

<details>

data.title: "Open with atom" context menu action should not open a new instance of the editor
data.body:
Using the "Open with atom" context menu shortcut, it can be a little frustrating when a new instance of atom has to start up just to see the contents of a file. True, i could drag the file into the current editor window, but usually i'm on another screen, or in a foreground explorer window somewhere... Seems to make sense that opening a new editor should happen via this context menu action (and should continue to be a user action from within atom or from the taskbar/application icon).

i'm writing of the behavior as it is in Windows 8 (Atom 1.12.7). i'm not sure if this behavior is the same on other OS's. Also, the system settings for enabling the context menu should all be checked on:
![open-with-atom-system-settings](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12688631/21417992/51a8597e-c7ec-11e6-9632-44c827b21635.gif)

**Current Behavior (using the "Open with atom" context menu):**
1. Open a file from one directory. Then open another file in a neighboring directory. Notice how the two tabs are within the same editor, but only the contents of the first directory make it into the tree-view:

![open-with-atom-neighboring-files](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12688631/21417942/e09c3d86-c7eb-11e6-878e-923709b3128e.gif)

2. Open a file or directory in atom. Then open another neighboring/parent/child/or even distant directory. Notice how the target is opened in a new instance of atom:

![open-with-atom-neighboring-directories](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12688631/21418025/7dae893a-c7ec-11e6-88ae-3e447e6254a2.gif)

i realize that this is probably trivial to implement. All that's required is "-a" being inserted into windows registry value for the atom cli interaction. i modified src/main-process/win-shell.coffee and tested a build... and it works.

**Suggested Behavior (using the "Open with atom" context menu):**

![open-with-atom-suggested-behavior](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12688631/21418055/ae712e6a-c7ec-11e6-947f-1285e0db9908.gif)

data.title: Template update
data.body:
* Update to use the latest issue and PR templates. 
* Update the contributing guide to reference the template files themselves

data.title: Limit line decoration update to visible row range
data.body:
Previously, if we had selections exceeding the visible range we still add line decorations to the cache for every row in the selection, including rows that were off screen and not rendered. This resulted in massive slowdowns when rendering with a large selection.

Here's some profiles showing me scrolling a 250,000-line file with a single selection spanning the entire file.

Before this change, 500ms frames and terribleness:

![screen shot 2016-12-21 at 6 27 25 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1789/21412186/8b7dac08-c7ab-11e6-9f60-5f3150ec155b.png)

After this change, the line decorations don't appear in the profile, frames down to ~10ms.

![screen shot 2016-12-21 at 6 28 43 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1789/21412208/c3c8208e-c7ab-11e6-91e3-3c95aaf82159.png)

/cc @maxbrunsfeld
